âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: There is already another minimum spanning tree puzzle on CG, but this one is different enough to justify it.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I love it when I learn a new algorithm.

Updated the "Leftover wood" section of the statement.
Updated values of test 1.

Previous version did not specify that it was first-fit:
A case like [600, 500, 300, 200, 200, 200]
First-fit is 3 logs used - [600, 300], [500, 200, 200], [200]
Optimal solution is 2 logs used - [600, 200, 200], [500, 300, 200]

But to find the optimal solution it can be up to 2^200 which isn't exactly feasible - So changed to ensure that it's first-fit.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: the description of the puzzle is very clear, the input and output format are clear and the constrains are well defined... i think this puzzle is sufficient complete to be published, the level hard i think it's oke... for me, there are two puzzles in one... one to find the minimum sum of length of trees to connect all islands (that might be a medium level puzzle) and other to count the minimum quantity of trees to cover the calculated distances (that might be  a easy level puzzle)... but you need to think how to face those two problems! that is hard.... i also think the tag distances might be suitable for this puzzle.
nice puzzle.... is the z coordinate the vertical axis?

Seems fun ! I managed to pass all testcases except last 3, I think it might be a precision issue in my code, I'll take a deeper look into it.

I noticed you wrote "Any angles should be truncated to 2 decimal places". A more efficient way to check if a bridge is walkable, in this case (45Â°) is to check wether its horizontal distance is longer than its vertical distance, i.e sqrt((x1-x2)^2 + (y1-y2)^2) >= abs(z1-z2).
Unfortunately, there is (at least) one testcase where this method doesn't work : validator Angle Checker. The angle between the Hometree and the first island is just over 45Â° (705.69m horizontally and 705.80m vertically), but using angle approximations to 2 decimal places, it is right on the limit (pi/4). I suggest to update the statement and testcases using this method (or to change the precision).
Thanks !

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Python does rounding differently than in other languages, so is the same solution possible in another language?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I support the inclusion of the game *Pandora's Bridges* on **Clash of Code**. It presents an interesting challenge by combining elements of 3D geometry, resource optimization, and network management. The game involves connecting floating islands while minimizing the amount of wood used, while respecting constraints like distance and bridge angles, making it a stimulating and rewarding problem. Additionally, the management of leftover wood and the requirement to connect at least one island to the Hometree adds an intriguing strategic layer. This game is an excellent opportunity for participants to test their skills in algorithm design and optimization while solving a complex and original problem.
Very good
Amazing story, but the new words would distract the coder.

Goal
* Please delete the extra space in "Pandorian meters ."

* It may be unclear whether angles should be rounded or truncated to 2 decimal places. Please clarify that in the statement.

* Please add "(d.p.)" after "decimal places".

* Please state whether two islands are considered connected even if they are connected only indirectly. For example, let's say there are 3 islands A, B and C which form a triangle. If A is connected to B directly and B is connected to C directly, do we consider that A and C are connected?

* Please state whether a coordinate difference of 1 in x, y or z direction corresponds to a distance of 1 Pandorian meter.

* (This point is for the sake of enhancing the realism of the environment setup only.) I assume each island occupies more than a single point on the coordinates grid? If so, I suggest to mention that the bridges should connect a particular landmark (e.g. island centre, town hall) which is present on all the islands. (See also # in Input section below.)

Input
* Please add "<<Line 1:>>".

* Suggest not to format "space" as a constant.

* Please add "of an island", or, (#) "of the [insert landmark name] of an island" after "3D coordinates".

* Please add "(all floats)" after "x y z".

Output
* Please change "2.d.p." to "2 d.p." (twice).

* Is it better to use "length" instead of "distance" (twice)?

Constraints
* First constraint: Please change 0 to 1.

Cases
* Please revise some of the coordinates to be negative numbers in the following cases:
  â€¢ Small Islands (validator)
  â€¢ Lots of Islands (validator)

Thanks.

Updated all but last of the goal section and penultimate in input. I'll consult a Avatar wiki to try find a suitable venue ðŸ˜„.

Thanks!
But this is not a clash of codeâ€¦?

Python, C++ and Java provides the same answers. I can't say for others as I haven't tested them.

edit:
Updated to truncated to 2 d.p. and removed the length of wasted wood output. Removed wasted wood as it's just the number of trees used * 1000 - length of bridge. It's nothing new as it uses the other two outputs in a simple calculation.

Specified angle should be truncated to 2 d.p. as well. I don't think rounding would cause any issues as 44.99 -> 45.00 would be valid as well but changed to be consistent with the output.

Thanks for the comment!

Your approach certainly should work, and is not something I considered... I've changed the statement to specify the angle is now strictly <45, therefore both methods should work. Also altered 'Angle Checker' test and validator to account for this.

As for the last 3 testcases, what values are you getting and what language? (I've also updated 'Lots of Islands')
Thanks! Yeah, the Z is the vertical axis. Do you think it's worth mentioning in the statement?

I might have missed the explanation, but should there be any explanation regarding the order: how do you define which is "first"? (The answer could be "yes" or "no". I haven't written a solution myself, so I'm not sure.)

yes

Changed the "Building Bridges and Leftover Wood:" section and the "The goal is...".

Reads a little clunky but I think covers everything - Specifies build order and the order of checking leftover.

Lemme know your thoughts.
Looks good to me. Thanks!

yes... probably in the input... i remember read this puzzle some months ago when i just started in this page.... i thought it was impossible for me to solve something like this... but now i see it clear and i want to try it
Added it to the statement, in the coordinates section - How did you get on with solving it?

the statement with the explanation of the coordinates looks nice ..... i didn't do the calculation to output the second line yet... but i have a correction for the output format for line 1, (i notice this due to Angle Checker Validator format)

change "truncated to 2 d.p." to "truncated to 2 d.p. and zero-padded."
Added to the statement and also altered "Lots of Islands" to end in a 0 so that case is in a visible test. Thanks for pointing that out!
what language did you complete this in?

OK, I don't see other issues after the update, so "venue" is the only outstanding matter.

Thanks! ðŸ˜Š

Changed to 'Tree of Voices'. 

Quick question about difficulty, is there a forum post with a guide I can't find or is it generally ambiguous?

All right! Would you please change "islands" to "island's" in Input section?

Unfortunately, there isn't any official guide on how to set the difficulty level for a puzzle. I myself generally follow the rules of thumb previously proposed by another moderator:
* if/else and possibly a loop is 'easy'.  
* Recursion, DFS, BFS, Minimax is 'medium'.  
* Something brute-forceable is easy or medium.
* Tricky or mathy stuff with multiple steps is 'hard' or 'very hard'
* Very hard: mini research projects requiring a lot of local coding and own test case development

There's an ongoing discussion here: https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/review-of-existing-puzzles/205533 . If more players join the conversation and show that they think there's an urgent need for a guide or review in this area, it'll strengthen our case to persuade the staff to take action.
And we need a concensus among ourselves first regarding the best way to set difficulty level.

Feedback from a fresh review:

Goal
* The phrase "the angle between the islands is LESS THAN 45 degrees" could be clarified. Since an angle requires a reference plane or line, consider rephrasing it to:
the angle between the bridge and the horizontal plane

Output
* Use "length" instead of "distance" for consistency with the second paragraph in the statement.

* Replace "d.p." with "decimal places" for clarity.

Thanks.

Thorough as always! That angle is implied but not stated, so have changed to your suggestion. Changed the output suggestions also.

Thanks!
